title: Q2的Adobe Beats营收为3.84亿美元，同比增长23％，VS EST。3.73亿美元，数码媒体的收入同比增长25％，创造性增长24％，并记录云30％
title_en: Adobe beats in Q2 with revenue of $3.84B, up 23% YoY, vs est. of $3.73B, with YoY revenues of Digital Media up 25%, Creative up 24%, and Document Cloud up 30%

note:
在与两名团队成员谈论2018年夏季学校的工作人员会议之后，我想我可以把自己放进你的鞋子。
 那一天，演示文稿并没有走路，我认为他们应该有。我们共同参加评估会议。我认为房间里的每个人都在这样的环境中，我希望他们以这种方式看到自己。我清楚地，我是最古老，最经验的 - 我应该以这种方式行事，在验尸的谈话中。但我没有。我有情感和过于连续的会议。我一定是针对你的愤怒言语，谁清楚地用这一天的日子。这伤害了你，它将所有的互动偏离从那时起。为此，我道歉。
  让我补充说，我很感激你以“我仍然使用的是，我不希望任何人思考另有思考。”它必须有倾向于将这两个想法一起编织。所以谢谢。
  最后，当你肯定回忆时，我鼓励你在2019年，亲自电子邮件，加入球拍领导;我甚至提出你可以取代我。我一直认为你的经历和你的外观会使我们的工作变得。我仍然这么认为。
note_en:
After talking to two team members who recalled our staff meeting at the 2018Racket Summer School better than I did, I think I can put myself into your shoesnow.
 That day, the presentations hadn’t gone the way I thought they should have. Wegot together for our assessment meeting. I think of everyone in the room as anequal in such settings, and I expect them to see themselves this way. I clearlyforget that I am the oldest and most experienced— and I should act this way ina post-mortem conversation. But I didn’t. I got emotional and overly intenseduring the meeting. I must have directed angry words at you, who clearly hadnothing to do with how the day had gone. And this hurt you and it definitelyjaded all of our interactions from then on. For this, I apologize.
  Let me add that I am grateful that you wrote in the spirit of “I am still usingRacket, and I don’t want anyone to think otherwise.” It must have beendifficult to weave these two thoughts together. So, thank you.
  Finally, as you surely recall, I encouraged you throughout 2019, in person andin email, to join the Racket leadership; I even proposed you could replace me.I always thought that your experience and your outside view would seriouslyimprove our work. I still think so.
title: 道歉

note:
Artsey是一种单手键盘系统，使用2x4布局中的8个键。该系统旨在易于学习，使用舒适，并且足够快，以进行实际使用。
   艺术是一个适用于各种能力的系统。标准系统可以通过四个手指完全操作，在一小范围的运动范围内。左右和右手使用有布局。几乎任何可以用正常键盘完成的计算机活动也可以通过艺术来实现。事实上，这个网站是完全与艺术委员会写的。
 为了实现完整功能，组合用于许多字母，符号，修饰符和正常键盘上可用的其他命令。虽然这些组合起初可能是令人生畏的，但是艺术品的基础知识可以在一个小时内学习。许多新的艺术用户能够操作他们的计算机，而无需在使用的前几天内引用布局图。可以使用专用实践超过50WP的速度。
     由于仅使用四个手指，因此拇指可以自由稳定并保持板。这简化了用于艺术品的便携式手持式键盘的硬件设计。这些板可以使用标准机械键盘开关作为信用卡等。
  QMK（QMK固件存储库）和ZMK（ZMK固件存储库）的GitHub页面上提供了artsey的实现。
note_en:
ARTSEY is a one-handed keyboard system using 8 keys in a 2x4 layout. The system is designed to be easy to learn, comfortable to use, and fast enough for practical use.
   ARTSEY is a system for people of all abilities. The standard system can be fully operated by four fingers over a small range of motion. There are layouts for both left- and right-handed use. Almost any computer activity that can be done with a normal keyboard can also be achieved with ARTSEY. In fact, this website was written entirely with an ARTSEY board.
 To achieve full functionality, combos are used for many of the letters, symbols, modifiers, and other commands available on a normal keyboard. While these combos might be intimidating at first, the basics of ARTSEY can be learned in under an hour. Many new ARTSEY users are able to operate their computers without referencing the layout diagram within the first few days of use. Typing speeds over 50wpm are possible with dedicated practice.
     Since only four fingers are used, the thumb is free to stabilize and hold the board. This simplifies the hardware design for portable hand-held keyboards made for ARTSEY. These boards can be made as small as a credit card using standard mechanical keyboard switches.
  Implementations of ARTSEY are available on our github page for QMK ( QMK Firmware Repository) and ZMK ( ZMK Firmware Repository).
title: 艺术 - 单手键盘

note:
如果你走向墙壁，光线将合同。你越靠近墙壁，越来越浓缩的光束变成了。当手电筒从墙壁上英寸时，你会看到一个紧张，明亮的光线，被阴影和黑暗包围。
 你的注意力很像是那个手电筒的光束。您可以紧密地专注于某些东西，或者您可以放松它 - 让它变得柔软和漫射。
 死亡不是一件事，但事情：情绪的过程，州的州，突然变化的关系，需要的嗡嗡行为，空椅，一个没有连接的拨打号码。在悲伤的离合器中，死亡可能看起来像一个事件，窗帘的跑步越来越多，我们都不能看到 - 但它也是一条路，旅程，一个过程。
  在我的书死亡的夏天外套中，我谈论人类需要分类和区分。我们想说：肯定死亡......
 我在呃看到一个Covid病人已经很久了，我不能更快乐
  我是纽约市的急诊室医生，在几周内我还没有看到Covid-19患者。让我的旧工作感觉很棒。
 在2020年3月，Covid淹没了我们的分校。起初，它只是一个手机 - 每天一个或两个科迪德患者。但在一周之内，病毒在每张床上都接管了每个床。急诊室的每一个班次都带来了一个无休止的患者，一个接一个地努力呼吸和绝望地需要氧气。 
Covid抵达我们急诊室的迅速令我们惊讶地带来了......
 在Covid-19之后，我们都悲伤。我们怎样才能死亡来术语 - 以及它教我们关于生活的方式是什么？
    我们正在前往西弗吉尼亚州的一路，到一个不起眼的两层殖民地，我的祖父遗骸被冲洗并奠定了观察。它一直在下雨，但显然没有人在这个雄厚的葬礼厅里一直在睡觉。他们一直坐在身体上。坐起来 - 和身体 - 整晚。
 没有良好的形容词来描述我对此的感受。我十七岁，悲伤，但我并不恐惧。震惊......
 几种策略可以帮助防止向下的螺旋 - 他们都开始伸出援手
  这是一个四部分系列的第二部分，防止抑郁症，一种可以在任何年龄袭击的严重和生长的精神障碍，如果未经治疗，持续和恶化。
 雨天经常让我失望。即使有点阴云密布也可以让我进入一个恐惧。有时候我只是因为没有好理由而变得喜怒无常。这一切都正常。但是，当悲伤的感情仍然存在日复一日的时候，我们中的任何一个 - 我，你，一个家庭成员或朋友 - 冒着陷入衰弱的抑郁症的风险。没有免疫力。然而，有效的预防策略。 
更广泛的世界仍然没有被解雇的时间越长，毁灭性新变种的风险就越大
  在最近由监护人报纸获得的一封信中，超过100名前总统和国家元首敦促世界上最富有的国家的领导者更多 - 筹备更多的资金，特别是更多的援助和资源 - 致力于制作和资源在全球分布疫苗。
 据守护者表示，“直到每个人都有安全的，就没有人安全，直到每个人都是安全的。
 这不仅仅是崇高的谈话，而且它不仅仅是为了未被移开的辩护。那是冷的现实。
 我正在阅读我的UMPTENTH新闻故事关于Covid-19科学，一个关于如何使室内空间免受感染的最新研究的故事，关于清洁表面还是改变空气更为重要。这令我困扰着我。不是因为它是沉闷的（当然，这是：有珍贵的少数方法可以使空气过滤和空气泵的边缘的东西）。但由于它对科学的方式。
 您认为，它报告的大部分研究是以互联网上互联网上的研究人员分享的预先印刷品的形式......
 这是一系列预防抑郁症的四部分系列中的第一个，这是可以在任何年龄袭击的严重和生长的精神障碍，如果未经治疗，持续和恶化。 
Naomi Osaka从法国开放的退出 - 沉淀着“巨大的焦虑”，这位23岁的感觉超过了强制性的新闻事件，“漫长的萧条萧条”她说她自2018年以来一直处理 - 突出了阴影的现实抑郁症世界，在任何年龄的任何年龄，我们中的任何一个都可以潜入我们任何年龄的常见条件，原因是明显或神秘的。
 对于2012年的PLOS学习，研究人员邀请了一个年轻女性进入了俄亥俄大学的实验室。
 这位女士了解到，她将参与“审美判断”实验。研究人员拍了一张她的脸，然后让她坐在持有两个物体的桌子上：计算机监视器和镜子。
 在监视器上，这位女士浏览了一系列研究所谓的“有吸引力的专业模式” - 所有这些都是女性。在这个漂亮的面孔的栏杆之后，女人的自己的照片出现在屏幕上。但这不仅仅是......
 尽管肠道健康意识升高，但IBS的治疗几十年来几乎没有变化
  你可能知道钻头：你看到一位新医生，必须回答一下你的病情很长的清单。对我来说，它是一种新的胃肠学家，漫长的历史钻头筋疲力尽。是的，我有火炬升起 - 是的，他们是痛苦的。我患有IBS-C，这比说“具有便秘的肠易激综合征”稍微有礼貌。尴尬，对吗？
 基本上，我的消化系统瘫痪了。它只是......停止。但当然，细菌不会停止;他们继续做消化事物的工作，并创造占用空间的副产品。很多空间。 ......
note_en:
If you walk toward the wall, the light will contract. The closer you get to the wall, the smaller and more concentrated the beam of light becomes. By the time the flashlight is an inch from the wall, you’ll see a tight, bright circle of light surrounded by shadow and darkness.
 Your attention is a lot like the beam of that flashlight. You can focus it closely and intensely on something, or you can relax it — allowing it to grow soft and diffuse.
 Death is not a  thing , but  things: a process of emotions, states of being, suddenly shifting relationships, the buzz of needful activity, an empty chair, a dialed number that doesn’t connect. In the clutches of  grief, death may seem like a single event, the running down of a curtain beyond which none of us can see — but it is also a path, a journey, a process.
  In my book  Death’s Summer Coat, I talk a lot about the human need to categorize and differentiate. We want to say: surely death …
 It’s been a long time since I saw a Covid patient in the ER, and I couldn’t be happier
  I’m an emergency room doctor in New York City, and I haven’t seen a Covid-19 patient in weeks. It feels great having my old job back.
 In March 2020, Covid flooded our ERs. At first, it was just a dribble — one or two Covid patients per day. But within a week, the virus had taken over every body in every bed. Every shift in the emergency room brought an endless stream of patients, one after another, all struggling to breathe and in desperate need of oxygen.
 The swiftness of Covid’s arrival in our emergency rooms took us by surprise…
 In the wake of Covid-19, we are all grieving. How can we come to terms with death — and what does it teach us about living?
    We were on our way to West Virginia, to an unremarkable two-story colonial where my grandfather’s remains had been washed and laid out for viewing. It had been raining all night, but apparently no one in this homey funeral parlor had been sleeping. They’d been sitting up with the body. Sitting up — with the body — all night.
 There are no good adjectives to describe my feelings about this. I was seventeen and grieving, but I wasn’t horrified. Shocked…
 Several strategies can help prevent a downward spiral — they all start with reaching out
  This is the second in a four-part series on preventing depression, a serious and growing mental disorder that can strike at any age and, if untreated, persist and worsen.
 Rainy days often get me down. Even a little overcast can put me into a funk. Sometimes I just get moody for no good reason. That’s all normal. But when feelings of sadness persist day after day, any of us — me, you, a family member, or a friend — runs the risk of plunging into debilitating depression. There is no immunity. There are, however, effective prevention strategies.
 The longer the wider world remains unvaccinated, the greater the risk that a devastating new variant will emerge
  In  a letter recently obtained by  The  Guardian newspaper, more than 100 former presidents and heads of state urged the leaders of the world’s wealthiest countries to do much more — to commit more money, in particular, but also more aid and resources — toward making and distributing vaccines across the globe.
 “No one anywhere is safe from Covid-19 until everyone is safe everywhere,” the letter’s signatories wrote, according to  The Guardian.
 That’s not just lofty talk, and it’s not just a plea for the sake of the unvaccinated. That is cold reality.
 I was reading my umpteenth news story about Covid-19 science, a story about  the latest research into how to make indoor spaces safe from infection, about whether cleaning surfaces or changing the air was more important. And it was bothering me. Not because it was dull (which, of course, it was: there are precious few ways to make air filtration and air pumps edge-of-the-seat stuff). But because of the way it treated the science.
 You see, much of the research it reported was in the form of pre-prints, papers shared by researchers on the internet before they are submitted to…
 This is the first in a four-part series on preventing depression, a serious and growing mental disorder that can strike at any age and, if untreated, persist and worsen.
 Naomi Osaka’s withdrawal from the French Open — precipitated by “huge waves of anxiety” the 23-year-old feels over obligatory press events and the “long bouts of depression” she says she has dealt with since 2018 — highlights the reality of the shadowy world of depression, an increasingly common condition that can sneak up on any of us, at any age, for reasons obvious or mysterious.
 For  a 2012 study in  PLOS One, researchers invited a young woman into a laboratory at Ohio University.
 The woman learned that she would be taking part in an “aesthetic judgment” experiment. The researchers took a photograph of her face and then asked her to sit at a table that held two objects: a computer monitor and a mirror.
 On the monitor, the woman viewed a series of headshots of what the study termed “attractive professional models” — all of them women. Following this barrage of beautiful faces, the woman’s own photograph appeared on the screen. But it wasn’t just…
 Despite the rise in gut health awareness, treatments for IBS have barely changed in decades
  You probably know the drill: you see a new doctor and have to answer a long checklist about your condition. For me, it’s a new gastroenterologist, and the long history bit is exhausting. Yes, I have flare ups — yes, they are painful. I suffer from IBS-C, which is slightly more polite than saying “irritable bowel syndrome with constipation.” Embarrassing, right?
 Essentially, my digestive system goes paralytic. It just…stops. But of course, bacteria  don’t stop; they continue doing the work of digesting things and creating byproducts that take up space. A lot of space. …
title: 同行评审的荒谬
